awd_titl_txt: Rehearsing Disaster: Understanding Earthquake Preparedness Behavior in an Interactive Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Through experiments and focus groups, this project uses interactive digital environments to investigate the mechanisms through which earthquake disaster preparedness behaviors are adopted and maintained. It explores novel communication tools for promoting those behaviors in the hard-to-reach demographic: 18-29 year-olds. Insights gleaned from the project will help shape communication strategies to solve the urgent societal problem of disaster risk reduction. The study location in the Portland, Oregon Metropolitan Area anticipates a potentially devastating earthquake on the Cascadia subduction zone. Digital media developed as research tools in this project will be released as outreach products, contributing directly to national welfare via resilience-building in the Pacific Northwest. Collaborations with local emergency managers ensure that communication tools developed for this project promote essential priorities and that research findings are delivered to the agencies that will benefit most from them. This scientific research contribution thus supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare. In this case, the benefits will be insights to improve earthquake disaster preparedness, which will save lives, economic losses, and reduce panic, anger and confusion during a future event.

 
This project addresses key gaps in current understandings of how social cognitive perspectives apply to disaster preparedness. Specific research objectives are to: 1) characterize the effectiveness of interactive environments for promoting multiple solution pathways and problem-solving related to earthquake preparedness; 2) evaluate the relevance of different approaches to observational learning related to earthquake preparedness; 3) quantify the effects of cooperation on confidence in and inclination to take preparedness action; and 4) assess the effects of social processing through digital networks on behavior adoption inclination and critical awareness. These objectives will be accomplished through four experiments using interactive digital media, supported by focus groups that ensure salience of the media to target audiences and add depth to experimental result interpretation. Pathways linking experimental variables, possible mediating variables, and key dependent variables including self-efficacy, outcome expectations, intent to act, and preparedness action will be elucidated via structural equation modeling. Extending the study of social influences on preparedness behavior into the digital arena is an innovation that resonates with the media consumption habits of the target audience. While most applications of social cognitive theory to the disaster preparedness context are cross-sectional studies, use of interactive digital environments permits an experimental approach with which to test and extend current understandings. The project also directly engages dozens of undergraduates in the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In environments subject to severe but infrequent hazards where first-hand experience is lacking, media play especially important roles in encouraging disaster preparedness. Using the Cascadia subduction zone earthquake as a case study, this project investigated ways in which, and the degree to which, interactive digital media can promote disaster preparedness behavior. We focused on 18-29-year-olds, a group that is commonly overlooked in messaging campaigns but that can substantially benefit national welfare via effective disaster response if barriers to its own preparedness can be overcome. 

Our investigation centered on experiments that documented the impacts of engagement with custom-built digital interactive environments on preparedness behavior as well as on important pre-behavioral cognitive constructs like self-efficacy, outcome expectations, and intent to act. We found that the engagement increased both self-efficacy and intent to act, but that changes in self-efficacy were tied to problems solved within the environment, while changes in intent to act were not. Moreover, changes in self-efficacy were durable over the timespan of 3 months, while changes in intent to act largely were not. This highlights the importance of accounting more explicitly for temporality in behavioral models and opens up new research avenues. Problem-solving progress in the interactive environment increased self-efficacy for related content and decreased anxiety. Coping with psychological trauma in the aftermath of a disaster is a concern of this age group, and information-seeking via web searching does not increase self-efficacy toward this goal. 

Both web searching and engaging with interactive environments stimulate self-reported preparedness action after 3 months, but our findings indicate that digital interactive environments are more compelling than, and can be considered as trustworthy as, conventional sources of disaster information. The desire to engage with disaster content is an essential first step toward initiating preparedness, especially among our hard-to-reach target demographic. One of the digital interactive environments released after our study has been used over 13,000 times among diverse constituencies, including public school students, emergency managers and their social media followers, and science museum members in Washington and Oregon. One of our experiments investigated the impacts on pre-behavioral variables (self-efficacy, intent to act, outcome expectation) of match between a participant's geographic location and/or dwelling type (house vs. apartment) with those depicted in the interactive digital environment. A lack of systematic differences suggest that the same outreach products will work well in various localities. Ongoing collaboration with local emergency managers has kept their communication priorities in the foreground of this study, most significantly their emphasis on cooperation and building pre-disaster connections with neighbors. Other significant broader impacts of this study include the direct involvement of nearly 70 undergraduate students in the project's work and curricular tie-ins that engaged dozens more.
